title: Beauvoir De Lisle
text:
<a href="General%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">General</a> Sir Henry de Beauvoir De Lisle (27 July 1864 – 16 July 1955), known as Beauvoir De Lisle, was a British <a href="British%20Army">Army</a> officer and sportsman. He served in both the <a href="Second%20Boer%20War">Second Boer War</a> and the <a href="World%20War%20I">First World War</a>.
Military career.
Born in <a href="Guernsey">Guernsey</a> and educated in <a href="Jersey">Jersey</a>, De Lisle was <a href="Commissioned%20officer">commissioned</a> into the 2nd Bn <a href="Durham%20Light%20Infantry">Durham Light Infantry</a> in 1883. He saw service with the Mounted Infantry in <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a> between 1885 and 1886, being awarded his <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">DSO</a> there, and was promoted to the rank of <a href="Captain%20%28BARM%29">captain</a> on 1 October 1891.
He studied at the Staff College in 1899. During the <a href="Second%20Boer%20War">Second Boer War</a> he commanded the Australian Brigade, a mobile column comprising the 6th Battalion Mounted Infantry, the <a href="10th%20Light%20Horse%20Regiment%20%28Australia%29">West Australian Mounted Infantry</a>, the South Australian Imperial Bushmen and the New South Wales Mounted Rifles. He was severely wounded and three times <a href="mentioned%20in%20despatches">mentioned in despatches</a>. Promotion to <a href="Major%20%28British%20Army%29">major</a> followed on 1 January 1902, and to the <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> rank of <a href="Lieutenant-colonel%20%28British%20Army%29">lieutenant-colonel</a> on the following day. During the early months of 1902 his brigade was stationed in <a href="Natal%20Colony">Natal</a>, but in April he left the command of this brigade and transferred to <a href="Transvaal%20Colony">Transvaal</a> where there was more intense fighting. He left <a href="Cape%20Town">Cape Town</a> for the United Kingdom in late May 1902. In a <a href="mentioned%20in%20despatches">despatch</a> dated 23 June 1902, <a href="Herbert%20Kitchener%2C%201st%20Earl%20Kitchener">Lord Kitchener</a>, Commander-in-Chief during the latter part of the war, described De Lisle as "an officer of remarkable force of character. He has soldierly qualities and is a fine leader." For his service he was appointed a Companion of the <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Bath">Order of the Bath</a> (CB) on 21 August 1902, and received the actual decoration from King <a href="Edward%20VII">Edward VII</a> at <a href="Buckingham%20Palace">Buckingham Palace</a> on 24 October 1902. After his return he formally transferred to the cavalry when he was commissioned major in the <a href="5th%20%28Princess%20Charlotte%20of%20Wales%27s%29%20Dragoon%20Guards">5th (Princess Charlotte of Wales's) Dragoon Guards</a> on 22 October 1902. The following month he was appointed in command of the 2nd Provisional Regiment of Hussars at <a href="Hounslow">Hounslow</a>.
He was appointed Second in Command of the <a href="1st%20%28Royal%29%20Dragoons">1st (Royal) Dragoons</a> in 1903 and then became <a href="Commanding%20Officer">Commanding Officer</a> of the regiment in 1906. He became a <a href="General%20Staff%20Officer">General Staff Officer</a> at <a href="Aldershot">Aldershot</a> in 1910 and in 1911 was appointed <a href="Commander">Commander</a> of <a href="2nd%20Cavalry%20Brigade%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">2nd Cavalry Brigade</a>. He served in <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> initially as commander of 2nd Cavalry Brigade on the <a href="Western%20Front%20%28World%20War%20I%29">Western Front</a> and then as <a href="General%20Officer%20Commanding">GOC</a> <a href="1st%20Cavalry%20Division%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">1st Cavalry Division</a> also on the Western Front in 1914.
He then became GOC <a href="29th%20Division%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">29th Division</a> leading the Division at the <a href="Third%20Battle%20of%20Krithia">Third Battle of Krithia</a> during the <a href="Gallipoli%20Campaign">Gallipoli Campaign</a> of April 1915 to January 1916. He returned to the Western Front in 1916 and fought at the <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Somme">Battle of the Somme</a> before moving on to become GOC <a href="XIII%20Corps%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">XIII Corps</a> in March 1918 and GOC <a href="XV%20Corps%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">XV Corps</a> in April 1918. After the War he was appointed GOC-in-Chief of <a href="Western%20Command%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Western Command</a>: he held this post until 1923 and then retired in 1926.
Retirement.
He was known for his <a href="polo">polo</a> skills and spent much of the years 1929 to 1930 training polo teams for the <a href="Hari%20Singh">Maharaja of Kashmir</a> in <a href="India">India</a>.
Family.
De Lisle married on 16 July 1902, at <a href="Stoke%20Poges">Stoke Poges</a> church, Leila Annette Bryant, daughter of Wilberforce Bryant, of <a href="Stoke%20Park%2C%20Buckinghamshire">Stoke Park, Buckinghamshire</a> (the proprietor of <a href="Bryant%20and%20May">Bryant and May</a>, matchmakers).
References.
